flow.context: Suzanne Natoli is the Business Development Manager at Kiawah Seabrook Exclusives — her job is convincing new property owners on Kiawah and Seabrook Islands to join their rental program. She has 15+ years in vacation rentals and owns the rental revenue projection pitch to prospective owners. The company manages 185+ vacation rentals (115+ Kiawah, 70+ Seabrook) from Johns Island, SC, acquired by Continuum Management Group in 2021, running on Track PMS with a 25-point turnover checklist and photo verification already in place. Strongest angle for Sam: RapidEye gives Suzanne a tangible owner-acquisition differentiator — AI-generated inspection reports she can put in front of prospective owners as proof of care, especially when competing against bigger Charleston operators like Stay Duvet (360+) and Island Realty (350+). No direct personal connection to Sam — lead with industry proximity and the Charleston coastal PM market.

gatekeeper_initial.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper_initial.say: Hey, could you get me through to Suzanne? It's Sam.
gatekeeper_initial.note: Say it like you know her. No last name, no company name. Casual. If they ask 'Suzanne who?' say 'Suzanne Natoli.'

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah, I work with a few other vacation rental managers down in the Charleston area. Would you mind letting Suzanne know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Don't pitch the gatekeeper. Give just enough to sound legitimate. End with a redirect question so you stay in control.

branches.label: She's not available / take a message

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally fair. We help a couple other property management companies with their inspection workflows — I sent Suzanne a note. Would you mind giving her a heads up that I called?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: This is your last shot. If they still block, take the voicemail or ask for the best time to catch her.

branches.label: Take a message / she'll call back

gatekeeper_voicemail.label: VOICEMAIL / NOT AVAILABLE
gatekeeper_voicemail.say: No worries at all. When's a better time to catch Suzanne — is she usually in mornings or afternoons?
gatekeeper_voicemail.note: Try to get a callback window before leaving a VM. If sent to voicemail, leave: 'Hey Suzanne, Sam Parks — I work with a few other vacation rental managers in the Charleston area on their inspection workflows. Thought it'd be worth a quick conversation. My number is [number]. Talk soon.' Keep it under 15 seconds.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Suzanne, I work with a few other vacation rental managers out on the Charleston coast — Kiawah, Isle of Palms, that whole stretch. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around?
opener.note: Casual. Feet-up energy. Don't rush the question. The Charleston coast reference establishes local credibility. Pause after the question and let her respond — silence is okay.

branches.label: What is this about? / Are you selling something?

heard_name_no.label: THEY HAVEN'T HEARD OF YOU
heard_name_no.say: Oh, guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call — I was actually looking at your owner acquisition page, the rental revenue projections you put together for Kiawah and Seabrook. I work with another property manager who was in a really similar spot to you guys and ran into something interesting. You got a sec?
heard_name_no.note: Transition naturally. Referencing her specific rental revenue projection page shows you did homework and anchors you as someone who understands her role. The 'you got a sec' is a soft permission check before the pain trigger.

branches.label: What do you mean? / Tell me more

heard_name_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_name_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you. What'd you hear?
heard_name_yes.note: Let her talk. Whatever she says, bridge to: 'Yeah exactly — the reason I was reaching out to you specifically is...' then go to pain trigger.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow? Or would later this week work better?
bad_timing.note: Give two options. Lock in a specific day and time if possible. Write it down immediately.

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION FALLBACK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? You can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit.
permission_fallback.note: Disarm with honesty. Most people respect the transparency and give you the 30 seconds. Smile when you say it.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and it's just not interesting?
permission_rejected.note: Split the objection. You're trying to find out if it's timing or actual disinterest. Either answer gives you a path forward.

branches.label: Softens up / okay what is it

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER — BDM ANGLE
pain_trigger.say: So I work with another vacation rental manager — similar size to you guys, about 200 homes, resort market. Their BD person was running into this thing where they'd sit down with a prospective owner and say 'we inspect every property, we have checklists, we do photo verification' — and the owner would just nod, because every single PM company on the planet says that exact same thing. There was no way to actually prove it. They couldn't show the owner what really happens between guests. And meanwhile they're competing against companies with twice their inventory, so they've gotta win on quality — but the quality story was just words on a page. Sound familiar at all?
pain_trigger.note: This is tailored to Suzanne's BDM role. The pain is: every competitor claims quality but nobody can PROVE it to prospective owners. Kiawah Seabrook competes against Stay Duvet (360+), Island Realty (350+). At 185+ homes they win on quality, not scale — but the quality story has no teeth. PAUSE HERE. Let her react. Do not fill the silence.

branches.label: Yes / that resonates / tells her own version
Not really / we're fine / our owners are happy

warm_reaction.label: SHE'S WARM — STOP PITCHING, ASK QUESTIONS
warm_reaction.say: Yeah, I figured. So when you're sitting across from a new owner prospect — like someone with a home on Kiawah who's deciding between you and one of the bigger operators — what do you actually show them to prove the inspection piece? Is it the 25-point checklist, or do you have something more tangible?
warm_reaction.note: She's engaged. DO NOT PITCH. Ask about her process. You know they market a 25-point checklist with photo verification — reference it to show homework. Let her talk about her pain and her pitch.

branches.label: Honestly we don't have great proof

neutral_reaction.label: LUKEWARM — PUSH THE PAIN DEEPER
neutral_reaction.say: Yeah, and I only bring it up because I noticed you guys are competing in a market with some big players — Stay Duvet's pushing 360 homes, Island Realty's at 350. At 185 properties you're clearly winning on quality and service, not volume. But when a Kiawah homeowner is comparing three PM pitches side by side, how do you make the inspection story stick in a way the others can't copy?
neutral_reaction.note: Name the competitors and their scale. This creates urgency by making the competitive landscape concrete. She lives this every day — acknowledging it shows you understand her world. Pause and let her respond.

branches.label: How do you help with that?

cold_reaction.label: COLD REACTION — AGREE AND REFRAME
cold_reaction.say: That makes total sense — with 15 years in this space you've obviously got the pitch dialed. I should have assumed you'd be all set, otherwise you probably would've reached out. Just so no one from my team cold calls you again — is it that owner acquisition is humming and this isn't a priority, or is it more that you just hate cold calls and I caught you at the worst possible time?
cold_reaction.note: Agree with her. Reference her 15+ years to validate her expertise. Then split the objection. You're separating 'I'm annoyed by this call' from 'I genuinely don't need help.' Either answer gives you a next step.

branches.label: Softens up / okay tell me more
This would be an ops decision, not mine

discovery_deep.label: DISCOVERY — DIG INTO HER PROCESS
discovery_deep.say: Got it. And when you close a new owner, what's the handoff look like? Like does the ops team — Ryan or the inspectors — do they loop you in when there's a condition issue, or do you only hear about it if an owner calls you upset?
discovery_deep.note: You're mapping her workflow AND namedropping Ryan (Director of Ops) and the inspector role to show deep knowledge. You're probing for the gap between BD promises and operational delivery — that's where RapidEye lives.

handle_ryan_question.label: HOW DO YOU KNOW RYAN?
handle_ryan_question.say: I've been looking into how your team's structured — saw he's running operations across both brands. I figured between him and Karen they'd be the ones closest to the day-to-day inspection piece. Is that right?
handle_ryan_question.note: Be transparent. You did research — don't pretend to know them personally. Naming Karen (GM) and Ryan (Dir of Ops) shows you understand the org and you're serious, not just dialing a list.

solution_bridge.label: SOLUTION — ONE SENTENCE
solution_bridge.say: So what we built — and this is why I called you specifically — we plug into Track, which I know you guys are already on, and we automatically analyze the turnover photos your inspectors are already taking. It generates an actual inspection report — catches damage, missing items, staging issues — no workflow change, no extra steps. And for someone in your seat, it means you can literally hand a prospective owner a sample report and say 'this is exactly what happens to your home between every single guest.' Nobody else in the Charleston market can do that right now.
solution_bridge.note: Reference Track PMS by name — they use TrackHS. Reference that inspectors already take photos (25-point checklist with photo verification). Frame the value in BD terms: it's a sales tool for owner acquisition, not just an ops tool. Deliver this in one breath. Then immediately go to CTA.

branches.label: That's more of an ops thing
We don't have budget for that
We already have something for that

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Would you be open to taking a look — maybe 20 minutes when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue? I could walk you through what one of those inspection reports actually looks like, and if you wanted to pull in someone from the ops side — Karen or Ryan — that'd be great too. I've got next Tuesday and Thursday pretty open. What works better?
book_meeting.note: Low friction. 20 minutes. Suggest she bring ops people — this seeds a multi-stakeholder meeting. Offer two specific days. Lock it in NOW. Don't give her room to think about it.

branches.label: Let me check my calendar / not sure
I'd need to check with Karen / ops team

meeting_nudge.label: NUDGE THE MEETING
meeting_nudge.say: Totally — how about I throw something on the calendar for Thursday afternoon, say 2 o'clock? Worst case we move it. That way it's on the books and you don't have another cold call to deal with.
meeting_nudge.note: Pick a specific time. Make it easy. The 'worst case we move it' lowers commitment anxiety. The 'no more cold calls' is a real incentive.

branches.label: I really need to think about it / send email

meeting_booked.label: MEETING BOOKED — WRAP UP
meeting_booked.say: Perfect. I'll send that over to suzanne at seabrookexclusives dot com — is that still the best one? Great. Really appreciate you taking my call, Suzanne. Talk to you then.
meeting_booked.note: Confirm her email. Send the invite WHILE on the phone so she gets it immediately. STOP SELLING. Don't add anything new. End warm and clean.

meeting_booked_callback.label: CALLBACK SCHEDULED
meeting_booked_callback.say: Perfect, I'll try you then. Appreciate it, Suzanne.
meeting_booked_callback.note: Write down the exact day and time. Set a calendar reminder 10 minutes before. Don't push for anything else right now.

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Especially with the Continuum structure — I'm sure anything new has to go through a few layers. Just so no one from my team bugs you again — is it that budget for this kind of thing is completely locked, or is it more that buying anything new puts you through the ringer with corporate?
objection_no_budget.note: Reference Continuum Management Group (parent company) to show you understand the approval chain. Split the objection: is it budget or process? Either answer gives you a path.

branches.label: Budget is locked / can't spend right now

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it — I should have assumed you'd be all set, otherwise you probably would've reached out. One thing before I let you go though — if nothing else, I could walk you through what other PM companies in the Charleston market are doing with their turnover photos to win owner pitches. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends. Would that be worth 15 minutes?
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first, then offer value without asking her to buy. The 'steal some ideas' framing makes it about HER getting competitive intel, not you selling. This is especially strong for a BDM who lives and dies by her pitch.

branches.label: Okay sure / that could be useful

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — ALREADY HAVE SOMETHING
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with 185 properties you'd have to have something in place. Is it that you're fully covered and love what you've got, or is it more that switching anything right now would be a headache you don't need?
objection_have_process.note: Split it. If they love it, ask what they're using — you get competitive intel. If switching is the issue, position RapidEye as additive: it layers on top of what they already have.

objection_happy_process.label: THEY'RE HAPPY WITH THEIR PROCESS
objection_happy_process.say: Love that. Out of curiosity — the 25-point checklist and photo verification you guys run after every turnover, is that all managed through Track, or do you have a separate system for the inspection side?
objection_happy_process.note: Show you know their specific process by name. This does two things: (1) demonstrates deep research which builds credibility, (2) gets intel on their actual tooling. Whatever she says, bridge to the additive pitch.

branches.label: It's through Track / describes their setup
I'm not sure / that's an ops question

no_switching_needed.label: NO SWITCHING — ADDITIVE PITCH
no_switching_needed.say: Yeah and that's the thing — we don't replace any of that. We plug into what you've already got and just read the photos that are already being taken. No new app, no new workflow, no retraining your inspectors or cleaners. It literally just makes the photos you're already collecting smarter. Would it be worth 15 minutes to see what that looks like? Even if you decide your current setup covers you, at least you'd know what's out there.
no_switching_needed.note: Key message: RapidEye is ADDITIVE, not a replacement. No workflow change. This removes the switching-cost objection entirely. For Suzanne specifically, the additive angle also means her inspectors don't have to change anything — it's invisible to them.

objection_corporate.label: OBJECTION — CORPORATE / CONTINUUM DECISION
objection_corporate.say: Yeah, totally makes sense — with Continuum overseeing things I'd imagine ops tooling goes through their team. Do you know if that'd be Stacy Charlton's world, or would it be more Ryan Greer on the operations side? I just want to make sure if I reach out, it goes to the right person and isn't a waste of anyone's time.
objection_corporate.note: Name-drop Continuum's COO (Stacy Charlton) and Director of Ops (Ryan Greer). This shows you understand the parent org and makes you sound informed. You're trying to get a referral pathway to the real decision-maker.

branches.label: Not sure / I'd start with Karen locally
I can bring it up internally

referral_to_ops.label: REFERRAL — SHE SAYS IT'S AN OPS THING
referral_to_ops.say: That makes sense — you're on the owner-facing side, not the inspection workflow side. Would the right person be Karen McFadden or Ryan on the ops side? I just don't want to cold call the wrong person and waste everyone's time.
referral_to_ops.note: Name Karen (GM) and Ryan (Director of Operations) specifically. Makes it easy for Suzanne to confirm or redirect. If she gives you a name, immediately ask if you can mention she pointed you their way.

branches.label: Names someone else (Debbie, Chandler, Zack, etc.)

referral_to_karen.label: REFERRAL TO KAREN
referral_to_karen.say: Perfect. Would you mind if I mentioned you pointed me her way? I'll put something tailored together so it actually lands and isn't just another random pitch. And honestly Suzanne — the BD angle is real too. If you ever want to see what those inspection reports look like as an owner sales tool, I'm happy to show you that separately. Appreciate your time.
referral_to_karen.note: Get permission to use Suzanne's name when calling Karen. Plant the seed that there's BD value too — she may circle back. Send Suzanne a follow-up email with the BD angle after you call Karen.

branches.label: I'd rather you didn't / just call her

referral_name_captured.label: REFERRAL NAME CAPTURED
referral_name_captured.say: That's super helpful. Would you mind if I said you pointed me their way? I'll make sure the outreach is relevant so it actually lands. Really appreciate it, Suzanne.
referral_name_captured.note: Write down the name and any context she gives immediately. Ask if you can use her name — this warms up the next call significantly. Call the referral TODAY while the connection is fresh.

branches.label: Prefer you don't / just reach out

referral_ask_general.label: REFERRAL — GENERAL ASK
referral_ask_general.say: No worries. Who on your team would typically own anything related to the inspection or turnover workflow? Even just a title would help me make sure I'm reaching the right person.
referral_ask_general.note: If she can't name someone, get a title or department. Anything that helps you navigate the org. If she mentions housekeeping, that's probably Debbie. If she mentions operations, that could be Chandler or Zack.

offer_internal_champion.label: SHE'LL BRING IT UP INTERNALLY
offer_internal_champion.say: That'd be awesome. How about this — would it make sense for me to send you a quick one-pager you could forward? That way you're not trying to explain what we do from scratch. And if whoever handles it wants to hop on a call, I'll make it easy. What's the best email — suzanne at seabrookexclusives?
offer_internal_champion.note: Give her a tool to champion internally. Confirm email address. Follow up in 3-5 days asking if she had a chance to share it. Include the BD angle in your one-pager too — owner acquisition proof.

branches.label: I'll just mention it, don't send anything

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair. One question before I do — what would be most relevant to include so it's not just another generic pitch that ends up in the trash? I can angle it more toward the owner acquisition side — like how you'd use this in pitches — or more toward the ops and inspection side. Or both.
send_email.note: Accept it and then ask what to include. This tells you what she actually cares about AND significantly increases the chance she reads it. Whatever she says, include a specific time suggestion in the email to connect.

branches.label: Tells you what to include / owner acquisition angle

send_email_confirm.label: CONFIRM EMAIL DETAILS
send_email_confirm.say: Got it. I'll send that over to suzanne at seabrookexclusives dot com. I'll include a couple times to connect in case you want to dig in after you read it. Appreciate you, Suzanne.
send_email_confirm.note: Confirm the email address out loud. Send the email within 30 minutes while the call is fresh. Subject line: 'Quick follow-up — we spoke earlier.' Include a specific meeting time suggestion. If she said the owner acquisition angle, lead with that in the email.

test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
test_drive.say: Totally respect that. You're probably not buying anything this week, and I wouldn't expect you to. But when budget does open up — or when Continuum's looking at standardizing inspection tools across their brands — the people who move fast are the ones who already know what's first on their list. Would you be open to just taking a look? Not a commitment, just so you know what's out there. Twenty minutes, tops.
test_drive.note: Frame it as future-proofing. Reference Continuum standardizing across brands — this is real, they acquire PM companies and have been centralizing ops. Makes the meeting feel strategic, not transactional. If she still says no, offer the email path.

end_graceful.label: END — GRACEFUL EXIT
end_graceful.say: Totally understand. If anything changes on your end, I'm easy to find. Appreciate your time, Suzanne.
end_graceful.note: Don't burn the bridge. Stay warm. Add her to a 30-day follow-up cadence. She talks to property owners all day — she might refer you later even if she's not interested now.

end_graceful_referral.label: END — REFERRAL CAPTURED
end_graceful_referral.say: Really appreciate it, Suzanne. I'll reach out to them and keep you in the loop if anything comes of it. Have a great rest of your day.
end_graceful_referral.note: You got a referral. Call that person TODAY while the connection is fresh. Mention Suzanne by name if she gave permission. Send Suzanne a quick thank-you email within the hour — keeps the door open for the BD angle later.
